title: Mob Boss (film)
text:
Mob Boss is a 1990 <a href="direct-to-video">direct-to-video</a> <a href="Sicilian%20Mafia">Mafia</a>-themed <a href="comedy%20film">comedy film</a> directed by <a href="Fred%20Olen%20Ray">Fred Olen Ray</a> and starring <a href="Eddie%20Deezen">Eddie Deezen</a>, <a href="Morgan%20Fairchild">Morgan Fairchild</a>, <a href="Teagan%20Clive">Teagan Clive</a> and <a href="William%20Hickey%20%28actor%29">William Hickey</a>.
The film features <a href="character%20actor">character actor</a> Deezen in one of his few leading roles, as well as guest appearances from many veteran character actors known for their "tough guy" and <a href="gangster">gangster</a> roles, including <a href="Mike%20Mazurki">Mike Mazurki</a> in his final screen appearance.
Plot summary.
Don Anthony (<a href="William%20Hickey%20%28actor%29">William Hickey</a>) is the head of California's largest <a href="crime%20family">crime family</a>. Unbeknownst to him, his voluptuous mistress Gina (<a href="Morgan%20Fairchild">Morgan Fairchild</a>) and his arch-rival Don Francisco (<a href="Stuart%20Whitman">Stuart Whitman</a>) have plotted a hostile takeover of the business, and Don Anthony is gunned down following a mob meeting. Lying mortally wounded in the hospital, Don Anthony directs his chief lieutenant Monk (<a href="Irwin%20Keyes">Irwin Keyes</a>) to locate his estranged son Tony to assume the family business and carry on the Anthony name.
Unfortunately for the family, Tony (<a href="Eddie%20Deezen">Eddie Deezen</a>) is a wimpy nerd with no idea of the true nature of his father's business. As Monk tries to transform the milquetoast geek into a fearsome gangster, Don Francisco attempts to overthrow him through Gina's powers of seduction, while a pair of bumbling hitmen (<a href="Brinke%20Stevens">Brinke Stevens</a> and <a href="Jack%20O%27Halloran">Jack O'Halloran</a>) try to bump Tony off at every turn.
Production.
The film starred Eddie Deezen who had previously worked with Fred Olen Ray on "<a href="Beverly%20Hills%20Vamp">Beverly Hills Vamp</a>". "I love Fred," said Deezen said the film was "so much fun to shoot. I had a ball. Morgan Fairchild, a lovely lady."
Reception.
Professional reviews of "Mob Boss" were moderately negative. <a href="Entertainment%20Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a> gave the film a "C-" rating, writing "This mostly rotten comedy from bad-movie king Fred Olen Ray ("<a href="Hollywood%20Chainsaw%20Hookers">Hollywood Chainsaw Hookers</a>") offers amazingly low-brow slapstick, but the cast has fun (especially Morgan Fairchild, of all people) and the liberal use of boingy sound effects makes for a few silly laughs". <a href="Allmovie">Allmovie</a> gave the film 1.5 out of 5 stars without a written review.
